Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Application of Entanglement Theory at Catalhoyuk, Turkey

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies how a socio-economic reliance on locally acquired resources can influence social development. Under the guidance of Dr. Ian Hodder, Adam Nazaroff will study the procurement and use of chert, a rock composed principally of microcrystalline silica, at the site of Çatalhöyük, Turkey. This site was occupied during the Middle Eastern Neolithic from 7,400 to 6,000 BC, and is particularly well-known for its magnificent artistic motifs, its large size, and unique ritual and architectural practices. A significant portion of this project will include large-scale surveys of the landscape surrounding Çatalhöyük in order to discover natural deposits of chert which may have been exploited during the Neolithic. Using a combination of visual, geochemical, and mineralogical analyses, Mr. Nazaroff will identify which outcrops were used by the people of Çatalhöyük to produce chert objects. By studying the different objects produced from each chert source, it becomes possible to identify the different facets of society which were reliant on the use of local resources. More broadly, by identifying how local chert deposits were important economic, social, and ideological resources throughout the development of this Neolithic community, Mr. Nazaroff's research will help demonstrate the range of social practices which were impacted by the local landscape.

While the Neolithic is a time of wide-spread social change, encompassing many crucial developments in human history, current theories often argue that these developments originated in a few key centers before spreading outward to the rest of the Neolithic world. As a result, many communities have been envisioned as peripheral to, or subjects of, a predominantly foreign phenomenon. However, this research will help explain how Neolithic groups also developed within networks of local practices, which aided in the production of a heterogeneous Neolithic landscape. By giving a voice to the role of local processes, this project stands to more thoroughly inform archaeologists of the myriad of processes involved in community development.

This research is well suited to provide a broader impact beyond the scope of the above topics. Evident in recent anthropological and economic literature is a growing recognition of the directive force of regional and global networks on economic practices and community identities. Researchers have looked to understand how the origins of materials used in the manufacture of commodities impact the overall economies in which they are situated. This project adds the strengths of an archaeological approach to this discourse by analyzing how long-term processes articulate with other socio-economic practices to impact community development. This is a stark contrast to modern economic policies pertaining to the mining, trade, and exchange of resources which are only interested in short-term gains and ignore the long-term and nuanced consequences of particular investitures. This project also operates at the intersection of various disciplines (archaeology, anthropology, geology, economics) to provide a thorough perspective on the role of local resources in informing social behaviors. Collaborative research with local academic and governmental institutions, incorporating Turkish academic and student researchers, will also bolster connections between local and international researchers across disciplinary boundaries, which will help to develop an enriched archaeological discourse.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to examine how people come to rely on the use of certain resources, and how this reliance shapes, and is shaped by, the development of large-scale sedentary communities. These goals were explored by studying the consumption of chert (a sedentary rock used in prehistory to make a variety of stone tools) at the Neolithic site of Catalhoyuk in Central Turkey. Exploring these themes archaeologically is benefical for two reasons: 1.) archaeological communities are rarely extant, and thus offer a temporally defined case-study whereby a trend can be examined from its inception, to its growth, and eventual waning; 2.) because these communities are rarely extant, most interpretations must be drawn from their material remains, thus offering a chance to observe in depth how specific materials facilitate certain social developments rather than favoring an anthropocentric viewpoint which favors the role of human agents.

Prior to this research, most archaeologists believed there to be no significant deposits of chert in Central Turkey. It followed that all chert tools at Catalhoyuk were thus imported from far-off locales (presumably in southeastern Turkey or northern Syria). The first step of this project was thus to confirm or deny this hypothesis. This was achieved by surveying multiple environments throughout Central Turkey for the presence of chert. After four seasons of work, more than twenty natural deposits of chert were located throughout the survey area. Next, chemical analysis of chert deposits and chert artifacts at Catalhoyuk demonstrated that more than one thousand artifacts were indeed made of materials originating from the located deposits. This confirmed that the community did in fact rely on the use of more localized resources, contrary to previous research.

Next, this project examined how chert from each known deposit, as well as those foreign cherts likely acquired through trade and exchange, were used at different points in the community's history. This was compared with other trends in the life of community, such as the relience on sheep or cattle, the use of nearby woodland resources or those further from the community, and the growing importance of ancestor worship and house-based cults across the site. This comparative study revealed that early in the community's history, cherts were acquired in tandem with other nearby resources. This efficient procurement scheme was likely a hold-over from previous strategies used by mobile hunter-gatherers prior to the establishment of the sedentary community.

However, as the community grew there was likewise an increasing reliance on cherts from far away, especially those acquired through trade with neighboring communities. This trend developed alongside the growing importance of social relations which were essential to the functioning of a large-scale sedentary community. Following several anthropological studies of the 1980's and 1990's, it was determined that foreign cherts came to be favored over locally available resources because of the fact that their trade helped to establish these essential social networks. The trade of chert, then, came to be a basis from which intercommunal relations could develop.

By the end of the community's lifespan, those social relations outlined above began to dismantle. Rather than strong communal networks, the site was characterized by individual household economies. As a result, the consumption of chert resources once again shifted towards a preference for more locally available cherts. In fact, for the first time in the site's history, different households were using different cherts almost exclusively. This speaks to the disjunction between household networks, and the growing independence of certain families from the larger community.
